scenarios.title: Telephone Contact Billing
scenarios.description: A CSS provider has a 12-minute phone call with an enrollee to check on their housing stability. The enrollee was distressed and needed support. Can the provider bill for this service?
scenarios.question: Is this telephone contact billable?

options.A: Yes, all phone calls with enrollees are billable
options.B: No, the call must be at least 15 minutes to be billable
options.C: Yes, but only if it's video call
options.D: No, phone calls are never billable

scenarios.explanation: According to page 12, telephone calls of at least 15 minutes are billable. Since this call was only 12 minutes, it cannot be billed.

scenarios.title: Age-Based Eligibility
scenarios.description: A 15-year-old youth who has been chronically homeless for the past year is referred for Supportive Housing services. They meet all other eligibility criteria including mental health needs.
scenarios.question: Can this youth be enrolled in CSS?

options.A: Yes, age exceptions can be made for homeless youth
options.B: No, they must be at least 16 years old
options.C: Yes, if they have parental consent
options.D: No, they must be 18 or older

scenarios.explanation: Page 9 clearly states that eligible populations for Supportive Housing services include individuals who are 16 or older. No exceptions are mentioned for younger individuals.

scenarios.title: Late Assessment Submission
scenarios.description: A provider completes an eligibility assessment on March 1st but doesn't submit it to Wellpoint until March 15th due to staff illness. Wellpoint receives the assessment on March 16th.
scenarios.question: Will Wellpoint accept this assessment?

options.A: Yes, assessments are valid for 30 days
options.B: No, the assessment is more than 10 business days old
options.C: Yes, if the provider provides documentation of the illness
options.D: No, assessments must be submitted within 5 days

scenarios.explanation: Page 22 states that the assessment may not be more than 10 business days old when submitted to Wellpoint. March 1st to March 16th exceeds this limit.

scenarios.title: Pre-Authorization Services
scenarios.description: An enrollee in crisis needs immediate CSS services. The provider begins providing services on Monday while waiting for Wellpoint's authorization, which arrives Wednesday.
scenarios.question: Can the provider bill for Monday and Tuesday's services?

options.A: Yes, crisis situations allow retroactive billing
options.B: No, CSS may not be provided or billed prior to authorization
options.C: Yes, with proper documentation
options.D: No, unless approved by supervisor

scenarios.explanation: Page 12 explicitly states that CSS may not be provided or billed prior to an authorization for service, with no exceptions mentioned.

scenarios.title: Service Limit Exception
scenarios.description: An enrollee has used 28 of their 30 authorized CSS days with 60 days remaining in their authorization period. They need continued intensive support due to a housing crisis.
scenarios.question: What should the provider do to continue services?

options.A: Continue services and bill after the period ends
options.B: Submit an Exception to Rule (ETR) request with supporting documentation
options.C: Wait until the next authorization period
options.D: Transfer the enrollee to another provider

scenarios.explanation: Page 23 explains that providers can submit an ETR Form with a signed Single Case Agreement Form and supporting documentation for additional units when clinically necessary.

scenarios.title: Critical Incident Reporting Delay
scenarios.description: On Friday afternoon, a provider learns that an enrollee was hospitalized Thursday evening due to a mental health crisis. The provider reports the incident to Wellpoint on Monday morning.
scenarios.question: Did the provider meet reporting requirements?

options.A: Yes, they reported within 72 hours
options.B: No, they should have reported on the same business day they became aware
options.C: Yes, weekends don't count for reporting
options.D: No, they should have reported within 24 hours

scenarios.explanation: Page 6 states that critical incidents must be reported to Wellpoint on the same business day of occurrence or provider awareness. The provider became aware Friday and should have reported that day.

scenarios.title: Overpayment Discovery
scenarios.description: During an internal audit, a provider discovers they accidentally billed for 35 days of CSS services instead of 30 days for an enrollee three months ago. They received $560 in overpayment.
scenarios.question: What is the provider's obligation?

options.A: Report and return the overpayment within 60 calendar days of discovery
options.B: Wait for Wellpoint to discover the error
options.C: Keep the overpayment if not discovered within 90 days
options.D: Report it at the annual audit

scenarios.explanation: Page 54 states that providers must return overpayments within sixty (60) calendar days after the date on which the overpayment was identified.

scenarios.title: Institutional Contact Frequency
scenarios.description: An individual had one psychiatric hospitalization 11 months ago that lasted 45 days, and no other institutional contacts. They have significant mental health needs.
scenarios.question: Do they meet the risk factor criteria for CSS based on institutional contacts?

options.A: Yes, one lengthy stay qualifies
options.B: No, they need frequent (2+) or lengthy (90+ days) stays
options.C: Yes, any psychiatric hospitalization qualifies
options.D: No, it must be within the last 6 months

scenarios.explanation: Page 9 defines frequent as 2+ contacts in 12 months and lengthy as 90+ consecutive days. One 45-day stay doesn't meet either criterion.

scenarios.title: Progress Note Requirements
scenarios.description: A provider writes: 'Met with client. Discussed housing. Client doing well. Plan to meet next week.' They include the date but no times.
scenarios.question: What critical documentation element is missing?

options.A: Enrollee's response to interventions
options.B: Exact start and end times
options.C: SMART goals
options.D: All of the above

scenarios.explanation: Page 63-64 requires exact start and end times (not rounded), detailed interventions, enrollee responses, and connection to specific goals in the care plan.

scenarios.title: Inactive Enrollee Disenrollment
scenarios.description: A provider has tried to contact an enrollee 3 times over 4 weeks using phone calls and one home visit. The enrollee hasn't responded to any attempts.
scenarios.question: Can the provider initiate involuntary disenrollment?

options.A: Yes, 3 attempts is sufficient
options.B: No, they need at least 4 attempts over 6+ weeks
options.C: Yes, if they document the attempts
options.D: No, only Wellpoint can disenroll

scenarios.explanation: Page 24 requires at least four attempts over a minimum of six weeks, with each attempt at least one week apart.

scenarios.title: Clean Claim Denial
scenarios.description: A provider submits a clean claim on January 15th. By March 20th, they haven't received payment or denial. The claim was complete and accurate when submitted.
scenarios.question: What is the provider entitled to?

options.A: Automatic approval of the claim
options.B: Interest on the payment if approved
options.C: Double payment
options.D: Priority processing

scenarios.explanation: Page 52 states that if Wellpoint doesn't pay the claim within 61 calendar days, they will pay all applicable interest as required by law.

scenarios.title: Wait Time Violation
scenarios.description: An enrollee arrives for their 2:00 PM appointment. Due to provider delays, they aren't seen until 3:15 PM. The provider didn't notify the enrollee of the delay.
scenarios.question: What should the provider have done?

options.A: Seen the enrollee within 30 minutes
options.B: Notified the enrollee immediately and offered a new appointment
options.C: Provided a discount for the wait
options.D: Apologized when they saw the enrollee

scenarios.explanation: Page 28 states that wait times shouldn't exceed 45 minutes, enrollees should be notified immediately of delays, and offered a new appointment if wait exceeds 45 minutes.

scenarios.title: TAP Funding Request
scenarios.description: A CSS enrollee needs $6,000 for first month's rent, last month's rent, and security deposit to move into an apartment. The monthly rent is $1,800.
scenarios.question: Can this be approved through standard TAP funding?

options.A: Yes, it's for move-in assistance
options.B: No, it exceeds the $5,000 limit and needs an ETP
options.C: Yes, if split into multiple requests
options.D: No, TAP doesn't cover rent

scenarios.explanation: Page 67 states move-in assistance is limited to $5,000 total. Amounts above this require an Exception to Policy (ETP) request.

scenarios.title: Employment Service Age Requirement
scenarios.description: A 17-year-old with autism spectrum disorder wants to enroll in supported employment services. They receive SSI benefits and meet all other IPS criteria.
scenarios.question: Are they eligible for IPS services?

options.A: No, they must be 18 for employment services
options.B: Yes, they meet the minimum age of 16
options.C: No, they need work history first
options.D: Yes, but only with parental consent

scenarios.explanation: Page 14 states that individuals must be at least 16 years of age for IPS eligibility. At 17, they meet this requirement.

scenarios.title: Treatment Record Access
scenarios.description: An enrollee requests copies of their treatment record three times in one year - in January, June, and October. The provider charges $25 for the third copy.
scenarios.question: Is this charge appropriate?

options.A: Yes, only one free copy per year is required
options.B: No, all copies must be free
options.C: Yes, but only $10 can be charged
options.D: No, unless pre-approved by Wellpoint

scenarios.explanation: Page 62 states that enrollees are entitled to one copy of their treatment record each year at no cost. Additional copies may incur charges.

scenarios.title: Supported Employment Units
scenarios.description: A provider bills for 8 units (2 hours) of H2023 pre-employment services for job coaching provided during a 4-hour shift. The provider was present the entire time.
scenarios.question: Is this billing appropriate?

options.A: Yes, partial hours can be billed
options.B: No, all 16 units should be billed
options.C: Yes, if documented properly
options.D: No, only face-to-face time is billable

scenarios.explanation: Billing should reflect actual services provided. With proper documentation showing 2 hours of actual job coaching during the 4-hour shift, 8 units is appropriate.

scenarios.title: Fraud Suspicion Reporting
scenarios.description: A provider suspects a colleague is billing for services not provided, based on enrollee complaints and documentation discrepancies. They're unsure whether to report it.
scenarios.question: What is the provider's obligation?

options.A: Report only if they have definitive proof
options.B: Report suspicions to the SIU hotline at 866-847-8247
options.C: Confront the colleague first
options.D: Wait for an audit to catch it

scenarios.explanation: Page 35 provides the SIU fraud referral hotline (866-847-8247) and indicates that suspected fraud should be reported.

scenarios.title: Enrollment Pause Impact
scenarios.description: During an enrollment pause, an enrollee's 180-day authorization expired 45 days ago. They still need services and meet all eligibility criteria.
scenarios.question: Can they be reauthorized?

options.A: Yes, current enrollees can always be reauthorized
options.B: No, they missed the 30-day reauthorization window
options.C: Yes, with an exception request
options.D: No, they must wait for enrollment to reopen

scenarios.explanation: Page 26 states during enrollment pause, reauthorization must occur within 30 days of expiration. After that, enrollees go on the waitlist.

scenarios.title: Claim Dispute Timeline
scenarios.description: A provider receives a claim denial on March 1st. They disagree with the denial but don't file a reconsideration request until May 15th, citing staff turnover as the reason for delay.
scenarios.question: Will the reconsideration be processed?

options.A: Yes, staff turnover is good cause
options.B: No, it exceeds the 24-month deadline
options.C: Yes, within 24 months from EOP date
options.D: No, without proof of good cause

scenarios.explanation: Page 58 states reconsideration requests are accepted within 24 months from the date on the EOP. This is well within that timeframe.

scenarios.title: Multiple Service Billing
scenarios.description: An enrollee receives both CSS (H0043) services in the morning and IPS pre-employment (H2023) services in the afternoon on the same day from the same provider.
scenarios.question: Can the provider bill for both services on the same day?

options.A: No, only one FCS service per day
options.B: Yes, if properly documented and authorized
options.C: No, different providers must deliver each service
options.D: Yes, but at a reduced rate

scenarios.explanation: With proper authorization for both services and appropriate documentation, providers can bill for different FCS services on the same day.
